course_title: National Cinemas: The Cinema of Federico Fellini
seats: Seats: Maximum Enrollment: 9 / Seats Avail: 5Waitlist Total: 0
class_notes:
(Same as ITAL 376 1)
This course provides an in-depth examination of the cinema of Federico Fellini, one of the most distinctive, celebrated and influential directors of all time. His vision and style were so innovative that a new adjective had to be coined: Felliniesque. In this course, we will tease out the meaning of this adjective by identifying, analyzing, and interpreting Fellini's artistic production in its aesthetic innovations and philosophical content while paying special attention to the Italian historical and cultural context of the post-war period. The course will be offered in conjunction with required in-class screenings, special events with guest speakers, and the exhibition "Fellini and Fantasy" hosted at the Carlos Museum which will display film scripts, photographs, program and press clippings, correspondence, and, most importantly, color drawings by Fellini representing characters or scenes eventually incorporated into his movies.
course_description: Close study of the development of a specific national or regional cinema in terms of aesthetic, theoretical, and sociopolitical dimensions. Weekly screenings required.
prerequisites: FILM 102 and (FILM 201 or FILM 202 or FILM 203 or FILM 204) or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.
